column2: The Command-line - Cat and Mouse
What you'll do
Start learning about the command-line, the most powerful tool on any computer. (Part 1 of 4)
Hey {{user_name}}! Ada's always saying we should search out new things to do - so I want to try teaching you some tricks in the Terminal!
The Terminal is mondo cool, it's where the REAL magic in the OS happens. You know those scenes in movies where they hack into computer systems?
That's supposed to look like the Terminal. I'm going to teach you the real stuff, though!
Just a couple things before we start - when I do text like this, it's important.
Text like this is a command - something you could type into the terminal. Pay close attention to spelling, captialization, and spacing, the Terminal is very picky.
Also, pay attention to the results of what you type - If there's an error, you probably mistyped something.
Let's get started - I'll open the Terminal open for you.
Nice. See that text on the left there? That's called the prompt. All we need to worry about right now is the part after the colon (:), because it tells you where you are in the filesystem.

The filesystem is all the files and folders on your computer - think of it like a big set of filing cabinets. Each cabinet is full of folders, and each folder can have other folders inside it, and so on. That's why we need something to tell us where we are!
Right now, the part after the colon (:) should show show ~ (tilde), which means we're in your home directory, where all your files are.
To see what's around you in the current folder, you use the command ls
ls is a command that lists everything in the directory you're in. It's like looking around in a room.

Type ls (lower-case L, lower-case S) into the Terminal, then hit Enter. In general, if I ever ask you to type something, you can assume that you should hit Enter afterwards. If you shouldn't, I'll make sure to telll you!
Using ls should have shown you a list of items, then given you a new prompt.
Whenever you see a new, empty prompt, the Terminal is ready for another command. It's super fast!
If you had already saved any files in your home directory, you might see them in the results of that ls.
Hmm, did you create a directory named yarnbasket? Let's check it out!
To go into another folder, you use the cd command.
cd stands for change directory (directory is another word for folder). Unlike ls, cd needs some information after it to tell it which directory you want to change to.
Since we want to go into yarnbasket, type cd yarnbasket, then hit Enter
Your prompt should now say yarnbasket, since you typed in cd yarnbasket.
Now that you're inside this folder, type ls again to see what's inside.
Huh, that's a lot of folders of yarn! Well, I guess we're going to have to investigate it. Who leaves all that yarn lying around?
Let's enter the directory redyarn - To do that, remember how we got here?
To go into another directory, we use cd. So let's type cd redyarn, that will get us where we want to go. Once you've done that, use ls to look around in this new directory.
Nothing here. Hmm. Well, now we need to get back out, and to do that we'll use a special version of cd.
The special command is cd (space) period period - written as cd .. It means "go up one level". In this case, it'll take us to yarnbasket.
Now that you've gone up one level, we should be back in yarnbasket. I wonder where you'd end up if you entered cd .. here. Where do you think we'd go? Let's try it, and after you do, be sure to ls.

Hey, look, we're in your home directory. That makes sense, since we started here, did cd yarnbasket (that took us into yarnbasket) then cd redyarn (which took us into redyarn), then cd .. twice (the frst one took us back into yarnbasket, and the second brought us here).
OK, let's get back to yarnbasket, so type cd yarnbasket.
And now ls again, so we can see all the other folders we need to check.
Next up, let's investigate greenyarn.
We'll type cd greenyarn, enter, then ls, enter.
Nothing again! Why is this called "yarnbasket" if there's no "yarn" in these folders? Let's go back, using cd ..
Now that we're back in yarnbasket, let's check that last folder. Take us into blueyarn (cd blueyarn), and then let's see what we've got! (ls)
Aha! Do you see that? Our ls turned up a "mouse"! No wonder there was no yarn, this mouse ate it all!
Fortunately, I have a perfect solution. Felix! Come take care of this mouse!
Nyan, brrrp? Miao&^w!
<Felix licks his nose, and vanishes into an air duct.>
I love that cat, but he drives me nuts sometimes. He never does anything when you need him to!
Well, if Felix won't help us, we'll just have to use a different "cat".
The program cat helps you open files - it shows their data on the screen, right in the terminal.

You can use cat on any file - just type cat filename - but only text files will show you anything you can read. If you forget to type a filename after cat, you can use Ctrl-C to get back to the prompt.
OK, let's check out that file - type cat mouse to cat the file named mouse.
LOL! Looks like Felix is playing pranks on us.
It says the mouse got away, huh? To "greener pastures". Maybe that's a clue to the color of the yarn he's hiding in!
Let's go check that other folder! To do that, we'll need to go back up to yarnbasket, then back down into the other folder. Remember, use cd .. to get out of a folder.
Now that we're back in yarnbasket, let's go into greenyarn, then use ls to see if that mouse is hiding there.
Ha! I see a new file! Let's cat that file and see if we got him!
Not again! This is a clever mouse, but he's running out of places to hide. Quick, back up to yarnbasket and then down into redyarn!
Ok, now that we're in redyarn, let's ls and see what's hiding in here.
Now we've got him! Let's cat that file!
Gotcha! But he is awfully cute, I suppose. We'll let him go today. After all, he isn't doing anything bad, really.
That was fun! You learned ls, cd, and cat - and I've got much more planned for next time!
Catch you later!
